items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October, and for the following 24 hours. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, and creating a natural tidal locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are closely monitoring the situation, and will issue any further warning messages if necessary. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Darlington, North Yorkshire, Westmorland and Furness

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon but no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible from 7.30pm tonight, Saturday 4th October, and for at least the next 24 hours. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. It is likely that we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few hours. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible from 7pm tonight, Saturday 4th October, and for at least the next 24 hours. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. It is likely that we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few hours. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 7:30pm and 9:30pm tonight, Saturday 4th October and tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October between 7am and 9am. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.97mAODN at 8:30pm on Saturday 4th October, which is 1.1m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level). The following tide sees a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.13mAODN at 8am on Sunday 5th October which is 1.16m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10pm and 12am tonight, Saturday 4th October, and 10:15am and 12:15pm tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. Tide levels will be high around the boatyard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.69 mAODN at 11pm, on Saturday 4th October, which is 0.93m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerley (mAODN is height above average sea level). The following tide sees a peak level of 2.60 mAODN at 11:15am, on Sunday 5th October, which is 0.87m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerley. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update you if anything changes. We will update this message by 3pm tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or if the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 10pm and 12am tonight, Saturday 4th October and 10:15am and 12:15pm tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.69mAODN at 11pm, on Saturday 4th October, which is 0.93m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerley and 2.60mAODN at 11:15 am, on Sunday 5th October, which is 0.87m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerley. (mAODN is height above average sea level). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and and will update you if anything changes. We will update this message by 3pm tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 12:00 on 05/10/25, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 11cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 5 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 05/10/25, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
River levels across the Upper Calder catchment are receding. The threat of flooding is reducing, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Further showers are forecast overnight but no further flooding is expected.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
High lake and river levels throughout the afternoon may lead to flooding.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.
Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the rest of the day.
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are beginning to fall at the at the Llanymynech river gauge. However, levels are expected to peak again this evening due to further forecasted rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible between 8pm today and 01:00 am tomorrow, 05/10/25. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. 

Llanymynech peaked at 3.84m overnight into Saturday morning 04/10/2025.

Further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours into early Sunday morning 05/10/2025. 

We expect river levels to remain high until Monday 06/10/2025. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 

This message will be updated by 10am on Sunday 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Lancashire, North Yorkshire, Westmorland and Furness

items.message: River levels have fallen overnight. Further rain is expected today and river levels will rise again, but they are not expected to reach the same peak levels as yesterday.

River levels remain high in the Upper River Aire catchment following heavy rainfall on Friday 03 October 2025 and Saturday 04 October 2025. 
Continued elevated river levels on the River Aire will likely impact areas near Kildwick and Cononley for several days.
Please continue to take care around any standing water on low-lying land and roads.
This message will be updated by 08:00pm on Sunday 05 October 2025, or as the situation changes.

The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon but no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and large waves this afternoon may lead to flooding from overtopping and sea spray. Flooding of roads, low lying land and exposed areas of the coast is possible. Property flooding is not expected. Flooding is possible between 3:45PM and 6:00PM on Sunday 05/10/2025. We are entering a period of high tides through the week commencing 06/10/2025, and this flood alert may be reissued in advance of future high tides. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9PM on 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.
River levels have fallen overnight. Further rain is expected today and river levels will rise again, but they are not expected to reach the same peak levels as yesterday.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: River levels in this area have now fallen below levels of concern.

items.description: River Ure at Boroughbridge Camping and Caravanning Site
items.message: River levels in this area have now fallen below levels of concern. A flood alert remains in force for the wider area.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 9:15pm and 11:15pm tonight, Saturday 4th October and 10am and 12pm tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.89mAODN at 10:15pm, Saturday 4th October, which is 0.92m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerley (mAODN is height above average sea level). The following tide sees a peak level at Clacton of 2.89mAODN at 11am, Sunday 5th October, which is 0.79m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerley. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 3pm tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or if the situation changes.

Large waves and sea spray are expected to affect the seafront as a result of Storm Amy between 04:15am and 06:15am, Sunday 05 October 2025. 

Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 3.75 mAODN at 05:15am, on Sunday 05 October 2025, which is 0.67m above tide tables, wind Force 7, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). 

The following tide on Sunday 05 October 2025 at 18:00 is currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. 

Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. 

We will update this message by 10:00am Sunday, 05 October 2025.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message:
Levels on the River Ouse have now peaked. However, flooding is possible through Sunday 05/10/2025 as levels remain high. 
Flooding is forecast to affect riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. No further significant rainfall is expected today, and we expect levels to fall slowly during the day.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. 
 
This message will be updated by 9PM on Sunday 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Strong winds and large waves this afternoon may lead to flooding from overtopping and sea spray. Flooding of roads, low lying land and exposed areas of the coast is possible. Property flooding is not expected. Flooding is possible between 4:00PM and 6:00PM on Sunday 05/10/2025. We are entering a period of high tides through the week commencing 06/10/2025, and this flood alert may be reissued in advance of future high tides. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9PM on 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force this morning, Sunday 05/10/2025.  A high tide this morning (Sunday) may lead to minor flooding along parts of the East Kent coast.
No property flooding is expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be on the East Kent coast around 10:15 AM on 05/10/2025, and around an hour later at 11:15 AM at Sandwich on the tidal River Stour. Flooding is possible 1 hour either side of high water at any given location.
Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths.
Coastal conditions are expected to improve by the afternoon and no further flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates in coastal defences.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it: For a peak level at Dover. The forecast high water is at 10:15 AM on 05/10/2025 with a level of 3.63mAODN with westerly force 6 winds.
We will remove this message by 01:00 PM on 05/10/2025.

River levels are rising at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 12:00 and 18:00 today, 05/10/25.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Predicted Peak :- Crew Green 5.0m to 5.4m 05/10 at 17:00. No other gauge locations are expected to reach flood alert levels. 
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until 06/10/25.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 16:00 on 05/10/25, or as the situation changes

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 9:45pm and 11:45pm tonight, Saturday 4th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.40mAODN at 10:45 pm, on Saturday 4th October, which is 1m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerley (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Margaret's at Cliffe to Sandgate
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force this morning, Sunday 05/10/2025.  A high tide this morning (Sunday) may lead to minor flooding along parts of the East Kent coast.
No property flooding is expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be on the East Kent coast around 10:15 AM on 05/10/2025. Flooding is possible 1 hour either side of high water.
Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths at sea level between St Margaret's Bay and Sandgate.
Coastal conditions are expected to improve by the afternoon and no further flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates in coastal defences.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it: For a peak level at Dover. The forecast high water is at 10:15 AM on 05/10/2025 with a level of 3.63mAODN with westerly force 6 winds.
We will remove this message by 01:00 PM on 05/10/2025.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 9:15pm and 11:15pm tonight, Saturday 4th October and 10:00am and 12pm tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. Tide levels will be high at Battlesbrigde, and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.89mAODN at 10:15pm, Saturday 4th October, which is 0.92m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerley and 2.89mAODN at 11am, Sunday 5th October, which is 0.79m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerley. (mAODN is height above average sea level). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 3pm tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or if the situation changes.

High tides, strong winds and large waves may lead to flooding.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible around the high tides this afternoon, 4/10/25, and early Sunday morning. Property flooding is not expected.

Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point, including Porlock Weir.

Strong winds will continue into Sunday morning with some showers possible today.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

The detailed tidal forecast, for those who use it, is for a peak level at Hinkley Point. The first forecast high water is at 5:30 PM on 04/10/2025, with a level of 4.73 mAODN with Westerly force 7 winds. The second forecast high water is at 6:00 AM on 05/10/2025, with a level of 5.06 mAODN with North Westerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels remain high following heavy rain yesterday.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning but no further flooding is expected.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high following heavy rain yesterday.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning but no further flooding is expected.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 05/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tonight between 7:30pm and 9:30pm, Saturday 4th October, and tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October, between 7am and 9am. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.97 mAODN at 8:30pm on Saturday 4th October, which is 1.1m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly (mAODN is height above average sea level). The following tide sees a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.13 mAODN at 8am on Sunday 5th October which is 1.16m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October.

items.description: Upper River Irwell catchment with Oldham, Bolton, Rochdale, Haslingden, Ramsbottom and Rawtenstall

floodArea.county: Blackburn with Darwen, Bolton, Bury, Lancashire, Oldham, Rochdale

items.message:
There is potential for some heavy showers in the next few hours, but the main band of rain has passed through and river levels are reaching their peak, if not already falling, and are below Flood Alert level.   

The flood alert has been removed but river levels may remain high for some time. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tonight between 7:00pm and 9:00pm tonight, Saturday 4th October and tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October between 6:30am and 8:30am  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. We expect high tide levels at Gorleston-on-Sea and water on towpaths and quaysides throughout Great Yarmouth. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Great Yarmouth of 1.95mAODN at 8pm on Saturday 4th October, which is 1.12m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level). The following tide sees a peak level at Great Yarmouth of 2.13mAODN at 7:30am on Sunday 5th October which is 1.18m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October.

River and lake levels remain high following yesterdays heavy rainfall. 
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site .
There are further rain showers throughout today, Saturday 04/10/25 which will keep river and lake levels high.
We are continuing to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 05/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely from 5:15am tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October, and for the following 24 hours. This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. Areas most at risk are in St Olaves, Somerleyton, Burgh St Peter, Oulton Broad and Beccles. Roads likely to be affected include Beccles Road at St Olaves, Geldeston Lock Lane, Gillingham Dam and Fen Lane in Beccles. We are currently monitoring the situation and will update this message if necessary. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely from 5:45am tomorrow morning, Sunday 5th October, and for the following 24 hours.  This is due to tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth and creating a natural tide locking effect. This will restrict the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. Areas most at risk are in Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall. We are currently monitoring the situation and will update this message if necessary. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  tomorrow morning between 06:00am and 10:00am, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. The location most at risk of flooding is the A12 at Blythburgh. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tomorrow morning at Lowestoft of 2.13mAODN at 8am on Sunday 5th October which is 1.16m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October.

This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely tomorrow morning between 6am and 10am, Sunday 5th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to Storm Amy. Areas most at risk are around Southwold Harbour, Ferry road, the bottom of Queens Road and Constitution Hill, North Road, the bottom of Pier Avenue and Mights Road in Southwold. Bridge Road and Hillside Road in Reydon. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tomorrow morning at Lowestoft of 2.13mAODN at 8am on Sunday 5th October which is 1.16m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 5th October.
